translated: One in whom the faculties are conquered is a conquered-faculty one, the Blessed One. One in whom fire is set is a set-fire one. Or a fire-set one, etc., according as the distinction is required.

original: 220. Karaṇe tu-chinno rukkho yena so chinnarukkho, pharasu.
analyzed: karaṇe tu chinnaḥ rukkhaḥ yena saḥ chinna rukkhaḥ
translated: But in the instrumental: A tree that is cut by him is a cut-tree one, an axe.

original: 221. Dinno suṅko yassa so dinnasuṅko, rājā.
analyzed: dinnaḥ suṅkaḥ yassa saḥ dinnasuṅkaḥ rājā
translated: One to whom a stake is given is a given-stake one, a king.

original: 222. Niggatā janā yasmā so niggatajano, gāmo.
analyzed: niggatāḥ janāḥ yasmai saḥ niggata janaḥ gāmaḥ
translated: One from whom people have gone away is a gone-people one, a village.

original: 223. Dasa balāni yassa so dasabalo, bhagavā. Natthi samo yassa so asamo. Ettha “attannassā”ti yogavibhāgena nassa a.
analyzed: dasa balāni yassa so dasa balaḥ bhagavā natthi samaḥ yassa so asamaḥ ettha yogavibhāgena nassa a
translated: The Blessed One is the one who has the ten powers, thus he is the one with ten powers. The one who has no equal is the one without equal. Herein, the “n” is the “n” of the word attanā, and the “a” is the “a” of the word asamo.

original: Pahūtā jivhā yassa so pahūtajivho, mahantī paññā yassa so mahāpañño. Dvīsu “itthiyambhāsitapumitthīpumāva ce”ti pumbhāvātidesā pubbuttarapadesu āīppaccayānamabhāvo.
analyzed: pahūtā jivhā yassa so pahūta jivhaḥ mahantī paññā yassa so mahā paññaḥ dvīsu ca iti pumbhāva atidesā pubba uttara padesu āīp paccayānam abhāvaḥ
translated: The one with a large tongue is the one with a large tongue. The one with great understanding is the one with great understanding. In the two words itthiyambhāsita and pumitthīpumāva, the “i” is the “i” of the word itthiyambhāsita, and the “a” is the “a” of the word pumāva.

original: 224. “Kvaci samāsantagatānamakāranto”ti antassa attaṃ. Kāraggahaṇena ā i ca. Itthiyamivaṇṇantā,
analyzed: kvaci samāsa anta gatānam a kāra antaḥ iti antassa attam kāra ggahaṇena ā i ca
translated: “Sometimes the final of a compound is elided” . Herein, the “n” is the “n” of the word attanā, and the “a” is the “a” of the word akāranto. By the word kāra, “i” is also included. Itthiyamivaṇṇantā,

original: tvantehi ca kappaccayopi. Yathā - visālaṃ akkhi yassa so visālakkho, paccakkhadhammā,
analyzed: tu antehi ca ka ppaccayaḥ pi yathā visālam akkhi yassa saḥ visālakkhaḥ paccakkha dhammā
translated: and the “a” is the “a” of the word kappaccayopi. As in the words visālakkhi and paccakkhadhammā,

original: silopo. Sobhano gandho yassa so sugandhi. Bahukantiko, bahunadiko, samuddo. Ettha
analyzed: si lopaḥ sobhanaḥ gandhaḥ yassa so sugandhi bahu kantikaḥ bahu nadikaḥ samuddaḥ ettha
translated: the “i” is elided. The one with a fragrant smell is the one with a fragrant smell. The one with many elephants is the one with many elephants. The ocean is the one with many rivers. Herein,

original: yadādinā rasso. Bahukattuko. Mattā bahavo mātaṅgā yasmiṃ taṃ mattabahumātaṅgaṃ, vanaṃ.
analyzed: yad ādinā rassaḥ bahu kattukaḥ mattāḥ bahavaḥ mātaṅgāḥ yasmin tam matta bahu mātaṅgam vanam
translated: the “a” is the “a” of the word rassa. The one with many verbs is the one with many verbs. The forest with many elephants is the forest with many elephants.

original: Tulyādhikaraṇo.
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇaḥ
translated: The one with the same case.

original: 225. Suvaṇṇassa viya vaṇṇo yassa so suvaṇṇavaṇṇo. Vajiraṃ pāṇimhi yassa so vajirapāṇi. Urasi lomāni yassa so urasilomo. Ettha vibhatyalopo.
analyzed: suvaṇṇassa viya vaṇṇaḥ yassa saḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ vajiram pāṇimhi yassa saḥ vajira pāṇi urasi lomāni yassa saḥ urasi lomaḥ ettha vibhati a lopaḥ
translated: He who has a colour like gold is Suvaṇṇavaṇṇo . He who has a thunderbolt in his hand is Vajirapāṇi . He who has hair on his chest is Urasilomo . Here there is elision of the case-ending.

original: “Atthesū”ti bahuttaggahaṇena kvaci paṭhamantānampi. Saha hetunā yo vattate so sahetuko, “yadā” dinā sahassa so.
analyzed: atthesu iti saha hetunā yaḥ vattate saḥ sa hetukaḥ yadā dinā sahassa saḥ
translated: “Atthesū” means “in the many” . Sometimes there is the first case-ending. He who proceeds with a cause is Sahetuko . He who is given at the time is So .

original: 226. Satta vā aṭṭha vā sattaṭṭha, māsā, etthaññapadattho vā saddassattho. Dakkhiṇassā ca pubbassā ca disāya yaṃ antarālaṃ, sā dakkhiṇapubbā, disā.
analyzed: satta vā aṭṭha vā sattaṭṭha māsāḥ etthañña padatthaḥ vā saddassatthaḥ dakkhiṇassā ca pubbassā ca disāya yam antarālam sā dakkhiṇapubbā disā
translated: Seven or eight are Sattaṭṭha . Months are Māsā . Here the meaning of the word is the meaning of another word. The space between the south and the east is the south-east, the direction.

original: Bhinnādhikaraṇo.
analyzed: bhinna adhikaraṇaḥ
translated: The compound is of different bases.

original: Appaṭhamantānanti kiṃ, desito buddhena yo dhammo.
analyzed: kim desitaḥ buddhena yaḥ dhammaḥ
translated: What is the meaning of “not the first case-ending”? The Dhamma taught by the Buddha.

original: Dvandasamāsa
analyzed: dvanda samāsa
translated: Copulative compound

original: 227. Nāmānaṃ samuccayo dvando.
analyzed: nāmānam samuccayaḥ dvando
translated: . The copulative compound is a collection of nouns.

original: Samuccayo, ti piṇḍīkaraṇaṃ ekavibhattikānaṃ nāmānaṃ yo samuccayo, so dvando nāma, idaṃ suttaṃ bahuvacanavisayaṃ.
analyzed: samuccayaḥ ti piṇḍīkaraṇam eka vibhattikānam nāmānam yaḥ samuccayo saḥ dvandaḥ nāma idam suttam bahuvacana visayam
translated: The copulative compound is a collection of nouns having one case-ending. This rule refers to the plural.

original: Cando ca sūriyo ca candasūriyā. Tiṭṭhanti tyādi-
analyzed: cando ca sūriyo ca canda sūriyā tiṭṭhanti tyādi
translated: The moon and the sun are Candasūriyā . They stand, etc.

original: Kriyāsambandhasāmaññato atthetthāpekatthatā, evaṃ naranāriyo, akkharapadāni.
analyzed: kriyā sambandha sāmaññataḥ attha itthā apekattha tā evam nara nāriyaḥ akkhara padāni
translated: And so with man and woman, and with syllables and words.

original: 228. Tathā dvande pāṇi turiya yogga senaṅga khuddajantuka vividha viruddha visabhāgatthādīnañca.
analyzed: tathā
translated: And so with pairs such as hand and foot, and with musical instruments, and with the limbs of the army, and with the various kinds of animals, and with the various kinds of opposites and dissimilarities, and so on.

original: Vividhenākārena viruddhā vividhaviruddhā, sabhāgā sadisā, vividhā ca te sabhāgā ceti visabhāgā. Yathā digusamāse, tathā dvande pāṇyaṅgatthādīnaṃ ekattaṃ, napuṃsakattañca hoti.
analyzed: vividhena ākārena viruddhā vividha viruddhā sabhāgā sadisā vividhā ca te sabhāgā ca iti visabhāgā yathā tathā dvande ekattam napuṃsaka ttam ca hoti
translated: The various kinds that are opposed are various opposites. Those that are similar are common. And those that are various and common are dissimilar. As in the compound digu , so in the pair hand and foot, etc., there is singleness and the neuter.

original: Cakkhusotaṃ, gītavāditaṃ, yuganaṅgalaṃ, hatthassaṃ, asicammaṃ, ḍaṃsamakasaṃ, kokālūkaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhusotam gīta vāditam yuga naṅgalam hatthassam asi cammam ḍaṃsam akasam kokālūkam
translated: Eye and ear, song and instrumental music, yoke and plough, hand and foot, sword and sheath, mosquito and gadfly, crow and owl.

original: Nāmarūpaṃ, nāmaṃ namanalakkhaṇaṃ, rūpaṃ ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ. Evamete dhammā lakkhaṇato vividhā, paramatthato sabhāgā ca.
analyzed: nāma rūpam nāmam namana lakkhaṇam rūpam ruppana lakkhaṇam evam ete dhammā lakkhaṇataḥ vividhā paramatthato sabhāgā ca
translated: Name and form. Name has the characteristic of bending; form has the characteristic of being molested. Thus these states are various by characteristics, and they are common in the ultimate sense.

original: Ādisaddenāññatthāpi. Yathā - bhinnaliṅgānaṃ - itthipumaṃ. Yadādinā rasso, dāsidāsaṃ, pattacīvaraṃ. Gaṅgāsoṇaṃ.
analyzed: ādi saddena aññattha api yathā bhinna liṅgānam itthi pumam yad ādinā rassaḥ dāsi dāsam patta cīvaram gaṅgāsoṇam
translated: And so with other meanings by the word ādi , as in the case of the different genders in man and woman, and so on. When ādi is used for the euphonic combination, as in slave and slave-woman, bowl and robe, and Ganges and sand.

original: Saṅkhyāparimāṇānaṃ - tikacatukkaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhyā parimāṇānam tika catukkam
translated: And so with number and measure, as in the case of the triad and the tetrad.

original: Sippīnaṃ - veṇarathakāraṃ.
analyzed: sippīnam veṇa rathakāram
translated: Of craftsmen: a wheelwright.

original: Luddakānaṃ - sākuntika māgavikaṃ.
analyzed: luddakānam sākuntika māgavikam
translated: Of hunters: a fowler, a hunter.

original: Appāṇijātīnaṃ - ārasatthi.
analyzed: appāṇi jātīnam
translated: Of those who have no property: a beggar.

original: Ekajjhāyanabrāhmaṇānaṃ - kaṭhakālāpaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: ekajjhāyana brāhmaṇānam kaṭhaka ālāpam iccādi
translated: Of brahmans who study one book: a Katthahāriyan, a Kālāyan, etc.

original: 229. Vibhāsā rukkha tiṇa pasu dhana dhañña janapadādīnañca.
analyzed: vibhāsā rukkha tiṇa pasu dhana dhañña janapada ādīnam ca
translated: The Vibhasha says that trees, grass, cattle, wealth, grain, country, etc.,

original: Dvande rukkhādīnaṃ ekattaṃ napuṃsakattañca vā hoti.
analyzed: dvande rukkha ādīnam ekattam napuṃsaka ttam ca vā hoti
translated: are either singular or neuter in the dvanda compound.

original: Dhavakhadiraṃ, dhavakhadirā, muñjapabbajaṃ, muñjapabbajā, ajeḷakaṃ, ajeḷakā, hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ, hiraññasuvaṇṇāni, sāliyavaṃ, sāliyavā.
analyzed: dhava khadiram dhava khadirāḥ muñja pabbajam muñja pabbajāḥ ajeḷakam ajeḷakāḥ hirañña suvaṇṇam hirañña suvaṇṇāni sāli yavam sāli yavāḥ
translated: Dhava and khadira, dhava and khadira, muñja and reed, muñja and reed, goat and sheep, goat and sheep, gold and silver, gold and silver, rice and barley, rice and barley.

original: Kāsikosalaṃ kāsikosalā.
analyzed: kāsikosalam kāsikosalā
translated: Kasi and Kosala, Kasi and Kosala.

original: Ādisaddena aññesupi vā. Yathā – niccavirodhīnamaddabbānaṃ - kusalākusalaṃ, kusalākusalāni.
analyzed: ādi saddena aññesu pi vā yathā kusala akusalam kusala akusalāni
translated: By the word “etc.” are included others also, as follows: Of the fixed opposites, the good and the bad, the good and the bad.

original: Sakuṇīnaṃ - bakabalākaṃ, bakabalākā.🔽Byañjanānaṃ - dadhighataṃ, dadhighatāni.
analyzed: sa kuṇīnam baka balākam baka balākā  byañjanānam dadhighatam dadhighatāni
translated: Of birds, the crane and the heron, the crane and the heron.🔽Of syllables, the curd-pot, the curd-pots.

original: Disānaṃ - pubbāparaṃ, pubbāparā iccādi.
analyzed: disānam pubba aparam pubba aparāḥ iccādi
translated: Of directions, the east and the west, the east and the west, etc.

original: Abyayībhāvasamāsa
analyzed: abyayībhāva samāsa
translated: Indeclinable compounds

original: 230. Adhisaddā smiṃ, tassa lopo. Adhisaddena tulyādhikaraṇattā itthisaddāpismiṃ. Niccasamāsattā ādhārabhūtāyamitthiyanti padantarena viggaho. Adhi itthiyanti ṭhite –
analyzed: adhi saddā tassa lopaḥ adhi saddena tulya adhikaraṇa ttā itthi sadda api nicca samāsa ttā ādhāra bhūtā ayam itthiyanti pada antarena viggahaḥ adhi itthiyanti ṭhite
translated: 230. The feminine is elided after a word ending in a. The feminine is elided after a word ending in a, because the two words have the same case-ending. The feminine is always compounded, and it is the basis of the compound. The compound is not resolved into its components. When the compound is resolved, it is as follows:

original: Upasagganipātapubbako abyayībhāvo.🔽Upasaggādipubbako saddo vibhatyatthādīsu samāso hoti, abyayībhāvasañño ca.
analyzed: upasagga nipāta pubbakaḥ abyayībhāvaḥ  upasagga ādi pubbakaḥ saddaḥ vibhati attha ādīsu samāsaḥ hoti abyayībhāva saññaḥ ca
translated: The indeclinable is a copulative compound with a prefix.🔽A word with a prefix is a compound in the sense of a case-ending, etc., and it is called an indeclinable.

original: “So napuṃsakaliṅgo”ti abyayībhāvo napuṃsakaliṅgo, yadādinā ekavacano ca.
analyzed: saḥ abyayībhāvaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ yad ādinā ca
translated: “It is neuter” means that the indeclinable is neuter, and it is singular by the rule beginning “yadā” .

original: “Saro rasso napuṃsake”ti rasso.
analyzed: saraḥ rassaḥ napuṃsaka iti rassaḥ
translated: “The vowel a is short in a neuter” means that it is short.

original: Aññasmā lopo ca.
analyzed: aññasmā lopaḥ ca
translated: And there is elision of the other.

original: Anakārantā abyayībhāvā parā sabbā vibhattī lujjare. Adhitthi, vibhattīnamattho ādhārādi.
analyzed: an akāra antā abyayībhāvā parā sabbā vibhattī lujjare adhitthi vibhattīnam atthaḥ ādhāra ādi
translated: All case-endings are elided after an indeclinable that does not end in a vowel. The meaning of the case-endings is a basis, etc.

original: Idhādhisaddo ādhārevattate, adhitthiiccetaṃ padaṃ itthiya miccetamatthaṃ vadati.
analyzed: idha adhi saddaḥ padam vadati
translated: Here the word a is used in the sense of a basis. The word adhitthi expresses the meaning of a feminine.

original: Samīpaṃ nagarassa upanagaraṃ. “Aṃvibhattīnamakārantabyayībhāvā”ti vibhattīnaṃ kvaci aṃ.
analyzed: samīpam nagarassa upanagaram vibhattīnam kvaci aṃ
translated: Near the city is upanagara. “The case-endings of indeclinables that do not end in a vowel” means that the case-endings are sometimes a.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ. Upanagare.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim upanagare
translated: What is the point of “sometimes”? Upanagara.

original: Abhāvo makkhikānaṃ nimmakkhikaṃ rasso. Anupubbo therānaṃ anutheraṃ, anatikkamma sattiṃ yathāsatti.
analyzed: abhāvaḥ makkhikānam nimmakkhikam rassaḥ anupubbaḥ therānam anu theram an atikkamma sattim yathāsatti
translated: In succession is in order of seniority.

original: Ye ye buḍḍhā yathābuḍḍhaṃ, vicchāyaṃ.
analyzed: ye ye buḍḍhāḥ yathābuḍḍam vicchāyam
translated: As many as there are elders is as many as there are elders.

original: Yattako paricchedo jīvassa yāvajīvaṃ, avadhāraṇe.🔽Ā pabbatā khettaṃ āpabbataṃ khettaṃ, mariyādāyaṃ, vajjamānā sīmā mariyādā, pabbataṃ vinātyattho.
analyzed: yattakaḥ paricchedaḥ jīvassa yāvajīvam avadhāraṇe  ā pabbatā khettam āpabbatam khettam mariyādā ayam vajjamānā sīmā mariyādā pabbatam
translated: As much as is the extent of a living being’s life is as long as life lasts.🔽Up to the mountains is up to the mountains.🔽Up to the burning is up to the burning.

original: Ā jalantā sītaṃ ājalantaṃ sītaṃ, abhividhimhi, gayhamānā sīmā abhividhi, jalantena sahetyattho.
analyzed: ā jalantā sītam ājalantam sītam abhividhimhi gayhamānā sīmā jalantena saha iti attho
translated: Up to the boundary is up to the boundary.🔽The word “up to” is used in the sense of a limit.

original: Āsaddayoge “dhātunāmā”dinā apādānavidhāneneva vākyampi siddhaṃ. Tathāññatra.
analyzed: dhātu nāma ādinā apādāna vidhānena iva vākyam pi siddham tathā aññatra
translated: The sentence is also established by the rule of apposition in the expression “the elements named” and so on. So too elsewhere.

original: 231. “Uttamo vīro pavīro” iccādo pana pubbapadatthappadhānattābhāvābyayībhāvābhāvo
analyzed: uttamaḥ vīro pavīro iccādaḥ pana
translated: But in the expression “the supreme hero, the best hero” the word “best” is not a indeclinable because the meaning of the first word is predominant.🔽It is a compound of co-ordination.

original: kammadhārayoeva. Evaṃ visiṭṭho dhammo abhidhammo. Kucchitaṃ annaṃ kadannaṃ. Etttha
analyzed: evam visiṭṭhaḥ dhammo abhidhammo kucchitam annam kadannam etttha
translated: The Dhamma that is distinguished in this way is the Abhidhamma.

original: “kada kussā”ti sare kussa kadādeso.
analyzed: kada kussa ati sare kussa kad ādesaḥ
translated: The food that is inferior is inferior food.🔽Herein, “kadanna” is a word formed by the addition of the suffix “deso” to the root “kussa” in the sense of “kad” and “kussa.”

original: Appakaṃ lavaṇaṃ kālavaṇaṃ, ettha “kāppatthesu cā”ti kussa kā, bahuvacanenāññatrāpi kvaci. Kucchito puriso kāpuriso, kupuriso vā, evamasurādi.🔽Pubbaparūbhayamaññapadattha - ppadhānābyayībhāva samāso;
analyzed: appakam lavaṇam kālavaṇam ettha kāppatthesu ca ati kussa kā bahuvacanena aññatra api kvaci kucchitaḥ purisaḥ kāpurisaḥ kupurisaḥ vā evam asura ādi  pubba paru ubhaya mañña pada ttha ppadhāna abyayībhāva samāsaḥ
translated: A little salt, salt for the time being; here, in the sense of “is suitable,” kusa has kā, and by the plural, elsewhere also in some places. A man with a bad belly is a kāpurisa, or a kupurisa; so also with asura, etc.🔽The compound of prefix and indeclinable, and the compound of indeclinable and indeclinable, are the two kinds of compounds with a preceding member.

original: Kammadhārayaka tappurisā dve, dvendo ca bahubbīhi ca ñeyyā.
analyzed: kammadhārayaka tappurisā dve dve indo ca bahu bīhi ca ñeyyā
translated: The copulative compound and the appositional compound should be known as the two kinds of compounds with a following member.

original: Samāso.🔽4. Taddhitakaṇḍa
analyzed: samāsaḥ  taddhita kaṇḍa
translated: Compound.🔽Taddhita

original: Apaccataddhita
analyzed: a pad ca taddhita
translated: Apaccataddhita

original: 232. Vāṇapacce.
analyzed: vāṇa pacce
translated: Vāṇapacce.

original: Chaṭṭhantā saddā “tassāpacca”miccasmiṃ atthe ṇo vā hoti. Vāti vākyatthaṃ. Ṇenevāpaccatthassa vuttattā apaccasaddāppayogo.
analyzed: cha ṭṭha antā saddā tassa apaccam iccasmin atthe ṇaḥ vā hoti vā ati vākyattham ṇena iva apacca atthassa vutta ttā apacca sadda appayogaḥ
translated: Words in the sixth case have ṇo or vā in the sense of “after that,” in the sentence. Vā means the meaning of the sentence. Because the meaning after that is stated by ṇe, the word apacca is not used.

original: “Tesaṃ vibhatyā” do tesaṃgahaṇena vibhattilopo. Tathottaratra.
analyzed: tesam vibhatyā tesaṃgahaṇena tathā uttaratra
translated: “Of those endings” means the elision of the case-ending by the inclusion of those. So also later.

original: “Tesaṃ ṇo lopaṃ”ti paccayānaṃ ṇassa lopo.
analyzed: tesam ṇaḥ lopam ti paccayānam ṇassa lopaḥ
translated: “Of those, the ṇ is elided” means the elision of the ṇ of the conditions.

original: “Vuddhādisarassa vā saṃyogantassa saṇe ce”ti saṇakāre pare asaṃyogantassādisarassa vuddhi.
analyzed: vuddha ādi sarassa vā saṃyoga antassa sa ṇe ca iti sa ṇakāre pare a saṃyoga antassa ādi sarassa vuddhi
translated: “If the vowel of the preceding word is a long vowel, and the following word begins with a vowel, there is lengthening” means lengthening of the vowel of the preceding word, if the following word begins with a vowel, and the preceding word ends in a long vowel.

original: Tassāpaniyame –
analyzed: tassa apaniyame
translated: The restriction of that is:

original: Ayuvaṇṇānañcāyo vuddhi.
analyzed: ayuvan ṇā nañ ca ayaḥ vuddhi
translated: And the lengthening of āyu and vaṇṇa.

original: Akārivaṇṇuvaṇṇānaṃ āeovuddhiyo honti, casaddena kvaci na.
analyzed: ā e o vuddhiyaḥ honti ca saddena kvaci na

original: 253. Saṅkhyāpūraṇe tyadhikāro.

translated: The following is the analysis of the numerals.

translated: “From dvitīhi tiyo”: tiyo. “Tiye dutāpi ce”: dvitīnaṃ dutā. Dvinnaṃ pūraṇo dutiyo, evaṃ tatiyo.

original: 254. “Catucchehi thaṭhā”ti thaṭhā. Catuttho, chaṭṭho.
analyzed: catucchehi thaṭhā ati thaṭhā catutthaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ
translated: “From catucchehi thaṭhā”: thaṭhā. Catuttho, chaṭṭho.

original: 255. Tesamaḍḍhūpapadena aḍḍhuḍḍha divaḍḍha diyaḍḍhāḍḍhatiyā.
analyzed: tesam aṭ ḍh upapadena aḍḍhuḍḍha divaḍḍha diyaḍḍha aḍḍhatiyā
translated: “Of those, aḍḍhupapadena aḍḍhuḍḍha divaḍḍha diyaḍḍhāḍḍhatiyā”:

original: Catuttha dutiya tatiyānaṃ aḍḍhūpapadena saha aḍḍhuḍḍha divaḍḍha diyaḍḍhāḍḍhatiyā honti.
analyzed: catuttha dutiya tatiyānam aḍḍhu upapadena saha aḍḍhuḍḍha divaḍḍha diyaḍḍha aḍḍhatiyāḥ honti
translated: Catuttha dutiya tatiyānaṃ aḍḍhupapadena saha aḍḍhuḍḍha divaḍḍha diyaḍḍhāḍḍhatiyā honti.

original: Aḍḍhena catuttho aḍḍhuḍḍho, aḍḍhena dutiyo divaḍḍho, diyaḍḍho vā, aḍḍhena tatiyo aḍḍhatiyo.
analyzed: aḍḍhena catutthaḥ aḍḍhuḍḍhaḥ aḍḍhena dutiyaḥ divaḍḍhaḥ diyaḍḍhaḥ vā aḍḍhena tatiyaḥ aḍḍhatiyaḥ
translated: The fourth with half is aḍḍhuḍḍho, the second with half is divaḍḍho or diyaḍḍho, the third with half is aḍḍhatiyo.

original: 256. “Saṅkhyāpūraṇe mo”ti mo, pañcamo. Itthiyaṃ pañcannaṃ pūraṇī pañcamī.
analyzed: saṅkhyā pūraṇe itthiyam pūraṇī pañcamī
translated: The fifth is mo in the filling of a number. In a woman, the fifth is pañcamī.

translated: When the compound is made of one and ten,

original: Saṅkhyāne uttarapade dviekaaṭṭhaiccetesa mantassa ā vā hoti. Ekādasa pañcīva. Evaṃ dvādasa.
analyzed: saṅkhyāne uttara pade mantassa ā vā hoti ekādasa evam dvādasa
translated: In a number, after the numeral dvieka, the vowel a or ā of the numeral is elided. Ekādasa, pañcīva. So dvādasa.

original: Yadādinā tissa teādese “ekādito dassa ra saṅkhyāne”ti dasasadde dassa ro. Terasa.

translated: When the numeral begins with eka, after the numeral dasa, the vowel da of the numeral is elided. Terasa.

original: 257. “Catūpapadassa lopo tuttarapadādicassa cucopi navā”ti catusadde tussa lopo cassa cu ca. Cuddasa.
analyzed: catu upapadassa lopaḥ tu ttara pada āt i cassa cu caḥ pi nava ati catu sadde tussa lopaḥ cassa cu ca cu ddasa
translated: The fourth is tuttarapadādicassa cucopi navā. The vowel tu of the numeral catu is elided, and cu is added. Cuddasa.

original: “Dase so niccañce”ti chassa soādese – “ḷa darānaṃ”ti dasasadde dassa ḷo. Soḷasa, aṭṭhārasa.

translated: The sixth is so niccañce. After the numeral dasa, the vowel da of the numeral is elided. Soḷasa, aṭṭhārasa.

translated: The twentieth is bā dvissa tū. After the numeral dvīsa, bā is added. Bāvīsati. The eleventh is ekādasamo.

original: 259. “Ekādito dasassī”ti itthiyaṃ ī. Ekādasī iccādi.🔽“Dvādito konekatthe ce”ti ko, dve parimāṇāni asseti dvikaṃ. Evaṃ tikādi.

original: Ṇe kate – “jhalānamiyuvā sare vā” tīha vākārena issa ayādese – dvayaṃ, tayaṃ. Evaṃ “gāmajanabandhusahāyādīhi tā”ti tā. Gāmatā, nāgaratā.

translated: In the passive, “in the sense of ‘two’ and ‘three,’ etc., in the sense of ‘arrow’ and ‘cow’”: in the sense of two, tayaṃ. In the same way, “in the sense of ‘village,’ ‘town,’ ‘kinsman,’ ‘friend,’ etc.,” tā. Gāmatā, nāgaratā.

translated: When the vowel of the base is elided, the vowel i is substituted by the rule of the cakāra group.

translated: The consonants of the words yavatā and talaṇḍaka are changed to jakāra, and the consonants of the words tādīnaṃ and cādayo are changed to yakāra.

translated: The state of being an ordinary man is puthujjanattam; the mere non-existence is ākiñcaññaṃ; the mere remnant is koṇḍaññaṃ; the increase is vuddhi.

original: Padāya hitaṃ pajjaṃ, dhanāyaṃ saṃvattanikaṃ dhaññaṃ, satito sambhūtaṃ saccaṃ, ilopo, tīsu na vuddhi. Devo eva devatā.

translated: The state of being delightful is ramaṇīyaṃ; the state of being proud is mānaññakaṃ.
